PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Second Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [13th January, 1992],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' - [Dr John Chen Seow Phun].

    Question again proposed.

     Mr Chin Harn Tong (Aljunied GRC)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government's policy as spelt out in the President's Speech is one which is full of compassion and concern for the people, particularly in the problems of education, welfare and health care. I wish to express my full support for this policy and to thank the President for his Speech.

    There are many ancient sayings in Chinese which are thought-provoking. However, there is one particular saying which leads me to respond differently. It says, " Fear not shortage but uneven distribution of wealth". In other words, a nation does not worry so much about material inadequacy, as it would about the uneven distribution of wealth. This saying has been quoted by many people and forms the basis of their discussion on social and economic problems. However, I don't quite agree with this saying.

    We often hear people say that it is not good for people to be poor as poverty will not only lower the standard of living of the people, but will also lead to endless

Column: 136

sorrow and suffering for the people. This is a sensible reasoning. If a country is poor, not only will the status of the country be lowered, but there will also be chaos and trouble therein. This explains the old saying, "Fear not shortage of wealth". However, I am very worried about poverty of a country. Singapore had been poor before. For those of us who are older, we have been through the agony of being poor. That is why poverty or shortage of wealth is something we should be afraid of.

    Today, Singapore has various achievements which are receiving praises from all over the world. This is because we have worked very hard, accumulated wealth, and built up a sizeable reserve. With this reserve, we are able to carry out all these great construction works, and earn for ourselves a wonderful reputation which is certainly the envy of many others. As such, we have to take good care of this wealth, and to handle our reserve with great care and prudence.

    From the recent experience of some countries, we realize the economic disasters and instability brought about by the equalitarian economic and social policies. Equalitarianism causes the people to lose the will to compete and the determination to improve productivity. No matter how hard they work, the reward is the same. Everybody gets the same. Who wants to work hard then? Thus, productivity drops and the economy of the country becomes chaotic. There will be more and more social unrest. The status and reputation of the country will go down the drain. That is why I am afraid of Equalitarianism. I fear "even distribution". The reason why productivity is kept very high in Singapore is that ourGovernment believes in "awarding the people according to their contribution". People are rewarded according to the growth in productivity. As such, we must continue with such a policy, maintain this spirit in order that we may have yet better achievements in future.

    However, as we enjoy the fruit of our hard work in the past, we must not forget that there are still a number of our compatriots

Column: 137

who are falling behind during all these years of competition and are unable to keep up with our pace of social development. They are living in poverty and are unable to enjoy the fruits of our success. They look at some of the Government's measures with a different view. Because materially they are worse off than their fellow citizens, they build up a psychological barrier towards some of the Government's policies. For example, the Ministry of Education is encouraging the concept of independent schools. These people worry that the independent schools will develop into some kind of institution for the elite. When the Ministry of Communications introduced the "Week-end Car" scheme, they say this scheme will only benefit those well-to-do people who have extra cars to spare. Thus, in their hearts, they begin to harbour ill-feelings.

    Although I do not agree with the saying of "Fear not shortage but uneven distribution of wealth", I feel that we should pay more attention to those who are less fortunate among us while we enjoy our prosperity and progress, and we should take practical action and measures to help these fellow-Singaporeans who are in real need of our assistance. To them, the immediate concern is their bread and butter. The beautiful prospect for Singapore in the 21st century is something which is too far beyond their reach. Even when this picture does become a reality, it has not much to do with them. We have to look squarely at their psychological barrier. When the various Government departments introduce any new measures, they should not assume that these measures will be readily acceptable to the people, and that there will not be objections. I hope that the various departments will monitor the feelings of the people, and pay attention to their psychological barrier. If any particular measure has to be taken, and such a measure will benefit Singapore in the long run, then they should explain it nicely and carefully to the people to overcome their psychological barrier.

Column: 138



    This is why I am full of praise for the policy announced by the President in his Speech. Because the entire policy is one which is full of compassion, and full of care and concern for those fellow-Singaporeans who are still living in poverty.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion by the Member for Hong Kah GRC.

    Sir, there are several important themes raised in the President's Speech. Members have debated them extensively. I would like to focus on how to strike the right balance between self-reliance and Government assistance. In my assessment, if Singaporeans are to progress as a nation and prosper as individuals, we must get this balance right. Too much individualism and we end up with a selfish and callous society. Too much Government intervention and we stifle private initiative and personal responsibility.

    Sir, getting this new balance will not be easy. On the other hand, we cannot just stick to what we have done in the past. Let me give three reasons why times have changed.

    First, the external environment. It is now more competitive and more complex. Competition for investments, technology and markets has intensified. In a way, Singapore has helped brought this about. Through our example and that of the NIEs, we have shown the world that economic progress is faster when you have an open economy, high savings rate, sustained investment and free trade. The lessons have been well learnt. Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia have adopted similar policies and their economies are taking off. China, Eastern Europe and Latin America have embarked on the same path. Even the more developed economies like Ireland and Spain are competing vigorously for foreign investments.

    To succeed in this environment, we must be prepared to compete, adapt and restructure. Some changes will be painful but we have no choice. We cannot insulate ourselves, we cannot opt out, nor can we

Column: 139

postpone the changes. Countries much larger than Singapore, like China, the old Soviet Union and India, have tried insulation and have failed miserably. Opting out will mean being left behind. Postponement means more drastic changes later on.

    Sir, it will be most ironic and tragic if after a quarter of a century of showing the rest of the world what a market economy can achieve, and country after country has adopted this strategy, Singaporeans themselves lose faith in the free market system, clamour for protection and are not prepared to change . I hope this does not happen.

    The second reason why a new balance between self-reliance and Government assistance is needed is the state of the Singapore economy. In the President's Speech, he noted that we are only half way towards becoming a developed country. The more difficult half remains ahead of us.

    Sir, in a more competitive environment and an increasingly sophisticated economy, there is a greater need for every worker, every supervisor and every manager to be more self-reliant, more creative and to exercise initiative. It is not possible for the Government to direct all the changes in a centralised fashion. What the Government can do is to provide a conducive framework, remove obstacles and facilitate the changes. If the changes are painful, the Government will assist in the transition. But the momentum for change lies with the people. If we are prepared to restructure and compete, we can make 4-6% economic growth each year. If we become more rigid and resist change, our economy will falter. The standard of living of our people will then stagnate.

    Sir, the third reason why I think we need a new balance between self-determination and Government intervention is the stage of our political development. Basic needs have been met and the standard of living of Singaporeans gets better and better each year. Singaporeans therefore want more choices and a greater say in matters that affect them. This is to be expected. It

Column: 140

is not possible for the Government to satisfy the wide array of needs of different segments of the population. Nor is it wise to do so. We should let the people take on greater responsibility on how to run their own lives. The setting up of Town Councils is an example of residents taking up greater responsibility in the running of their housing estates. The approach of "Many Helping Hands" ensures that looking after the disadvantaged in society draws upon the community for support, and not fall on the Government alone.

    In my assessment, the new balance calls for more self-reliance and personal responsibility and less Government intervention. However, please do not misunderstand me. I am not advocating for the complete withdrawal of Government intervention. It may not be appropriate for a distinguished gathering like this, but let me use the well-worn but local analogy of brandy and water. In the past, we may have recourse to a stiff brandy on the rocks. Now we should lighten up with less brandy, more water. In fact, we should encourage different drinks, some with brandy, some without. If a chill wind should befall us, heaven forbid, we may still need the original brew to fortify us. But in the present competitive and rapidly changing environment before us, we need Government to be of a lighter touch, more selective, less pervasive. The Government and the people will have to find this new balance in each major issue. Let me illustrate how this balance is evolving in health care.

    The Government encourages self-reliance and personal responsibility through the Medisave approach. This will be reinforced by the healthy lifestyle campaign which will highlight the crucial role each individual plays in determining his future health care burden. On its part, the Government implemented MediShield so that the people are insured against catastrophic illnesses. The Government is also committed to maintaining the heavily subsidised C and B2 wards to ensure that basic health care is affordable to all Singaporeans. Since older as well as self-employed

Column: 141

Singaporeans may not have accumulated the necessary Medisave accounts to meet their needs, the Government will assist them through the Medifund proposal. As several of my colleagues observed, many developed countries are grappling with rising health care costs and ballooning state subsidies. As an aside, I might add that the French like their cognac neat, and this is reflected in the deep troubles of their health care.

    In Singapore, we are evolving our own solution. I think we are approaching the right mix. So long as we emphasise self-reliance and personal responsibility, we will minimise waste and dampen unreasonable demand. At the same time, the Government will restructure the hospitals to keep costs down and provide safety nets in the form of subsidised wards and Medifund.

    Singaporeans should not be apprehensive about seeking this new balance. This Government has kept faith with the people over 32 years. As a result, the people have prospered and the standard of living has gone up. The Member for Potong Pasir, however, has claimed otherwise. He claimed that his engineer friend in 1972 earned $1,600. A fresh engineering graduate today earns $1,800 and can afford much less. The Member for Chua Chu Kang has corrected him. I would like to add that unlike many countries, what our people earn in Singapore dollars have held up in value. In 1972 and 1973 when I was a student in England, the pound was strong. It was nearly S$7 to a pound. Today, it is only S$3 to a pound. I remember it was S$3 to a US dollar in those days. Today, it is S$1.65 to US$1. It was also S$3 to A$1. Today, it is S$1.20. Even more dramatic, it was S$3 to NZ$1. Today, it takes only 90 Singapore cents to buy NZ$1.

    What is most remarkable of all is that we kept the value of the Singapore dollar up, while keeping interest rates low. Mr Speaker, Sir, many governments allow wages to rise, but the value of their currencies to fall. In Singapore, our wages go up and we keep our Singapore dollar up.

Column: 142



    The Ministry of Trade and Industry has provided data to debunk assertions that people are less well off, again echoed by the Member for Potong Pasir yesterday. I am sure it will do so again.

    Let me, however, just focus on housing where the standard of living has improved tremendously. In 1980, only 59% of Singaporeans owned their homes. Today, 90% own their homes. More recently, when I joined the Ministry of National Development in 1987, 30% of applications for HDB flats were upgraders. Today, 50% of applications are upgraders, and the numbers have not dropped. In the last quarter, HDB received 32,000 applications. If the people are less well off, as the Member for Potong Pasir alleged, how is it that HDB received so many applications to upgrade to 5-room and Executive flats?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, let me conclude by returning to the original theme of my remarks. New circumstances require the Government and the people to seek a new balance between self-reliance and Government assistance. A new consensus, a new partnership, is being forged. Some people are apprehensive. Their fears are unfounded. This Government has kept faith with the people for 32 years and the people have prospered. In the President's Speech, the Government again demonstrated unequivocally its commitment in education, health care and housing.

    That is why, Mr Speaker, Sir, I support the motion.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Eunos GRC): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am indeed heartened to note from the outset that the President has stated very clearly that the Government will now translate its long-term goals into immediate programmes, so that Singaporeans will be better off by the end of this term of Parliament. I also note that the President had, in his usual amiable and paternal style, gently reminded Singaporeans against being lulled into complacency by our achievements and success so far.

    Singapore has achieved much and can be proud of her success. But this is not a 100-metre dash where the race is over in 10 seconds. We are in a circuit race that continues on and on, in a medley where

Column: 143

we can expect not only a change in the team's runners, but also a change in the way the race would be run. The baton has now been passed on to the next generation of Singaporeans to run the Next Lap. Can we run as fleet-footed as our forefathers when we were required to run without our shoes on? Or have our soles been so pampered with the likes of Reebok and Bally that we have now developed Achilles heels?

    The world envies us. As with all envies, it breeds a burning desire for the envious to outdo the envied. Therefore, it comes timely when the President reminded Singaporeans that the basics have not changed. The law for survival has not changed, however secure our prosperity may appear. We must constantly keep ourselves trim and fit, agile and keen, eager to change in order to keep ahead, although no longer lean and hungry.

    Sir, the good life that this PAP Government has consistently dished out to Singaporeans might have created an equally consistent yearning for more, and an unrealistic expectation that this Government can unilaterally continue to deliver the goods. That good life is therefore a matter of course for Singaporeans. This is not so. To believe that this is so will be suicidal.

    As our economy matures, it is not expected to grow as fast. The challenge before us is how do we get Singaporeans, especially younger Singaporeans who had not felt or seen acute hunger, to accept that whereas 8-10% annual growth was normal, a 5-7% growth henceforth will be very good? How do we get the McDonald kids to understand that the McDonald restaurants are here because we had worked hard and they knew we can pay for their food and services? And not because they have an altruistic mission to provide air-conditioned comfort to our kids. The closing down of the Orchard Road thoroughfare for merry making and dance is only possible because we had worked hard and needed to unwind for some relaxation. And not because we have become a fun seeking lot.

    Sir, a basic assumption in the

Column: 144

President's Address is that our economy will continue to grow at 5-7% per annum, to generate enough economic wealth to pay for the various programmes in the Next Lap. While this assumption is reasonable, there is a remote possibility that we may experience yet another economic recession before the mid-1990s. The current economic recession in the US and some developed countries, if prolonged, will have an impact on us, sooner or later. And if our economy really back-pedals, would we be able to resist the temptation of digging into our reserves to pay for the various programmes in the Next Lap? This temptation will become even more enticing when people would emerge to exploit the situation, to appeal to emotions rather than reasons. Would we be as objective then? Can we afford to follow the path of some developed countries in giving free hand-outs to their citizens? Look at what happened to these countries. Singapore cannot afford to err in the same disastrous manner.

    Sir, I therefore would like to suggest that if the Singapore economy really back-pedals within this term of Parliament, let us not try to push through the implementation of the various programmes in the Next Lap. Singaporeans must have the gumption to accept lower growth and come to terms with lower expectations. Singaporeans must realise that unless we are united as one people, unless we continue to work hard and unless there is economic growth, there can be no reward and progress. Only then will we thrive as a people even in times of adversity. I therefore urge Singaporeans to be realistic in their expectations.

    Sir, I commend this Government for once again stressing the importance of educa-tion. Education is life long. The pursuit of higher education does not stop or even slow down with age. No one should consider himself as educated enough. The more he perseveres to learn, the more he works to acquire knowledge and skill, the more useful and able he will become.

    The proposed setting up of an Open University and the Institute of Technical Education cannot be more opportune.

Column: 145



    Many have missed a formal education due to personal circumstances and not by choice. Some come from large families that could not afford an education except for the younger siblings. So now Singaporeans will be given a chance to catch up. And with the setting up of a fourth Polytechnic, there would be opportunities galore for all who long to fulfil their aspirations. With more people better qualified, their expectations will correspondingly become higher. Quite understandably, they would expect a new and better sounding job title, and higher pay. If the economy can expand at the rate of 5-7% per annum, as predicted, the expectations of many of this enlarged pool of graduates could be satisfied. But if this growth target is not met, the scenario can be quite different. I therefore once again urge Singaporeans who wish to better themselves through education to be realistic in their expectations.

    Sir, the decentralisation of the public sector's personnel management system is indeed a move in the right direction. With the civil service becoming less fettered and a more responsive and competitive employer, we should see more able talents from the private sector joining the civil service. Needless to say, a strong civil service - the actual proposers and formulators of Government policies - will make a stronger and more prosperous nation.

    While I look forward to a civil service that is more liberated, I wonder whether it would thus become too competitive for the good of the economy in general, and the private sector in particular. If the civil service will no longer be constrained by a salary scale that it could offer to recruit a talent, it will easily have all the financial means to outpay any employer in the private sector for this talent.

    In the past, the private sector had been accused to have poached good people from the public sector. With the revamp of the civil service, I hope it will not be a case of the public sector poaching talents from the private sector, with even greater vengeance! The private sector can indeed

Column: 146

ill afford to lose all its good men to the civil service and still remain internationally competitive. We must therefore ensure that there is a good spread of talents between the two sectors.

    With that, Sir, I beg to support this Government's philosophy and policies laid out in the President's Address.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, for this opportunity to speak in Parliament today, I must first of all thank the voters in Hougang Constituency for their support. Although I was educated in Chinese and I have chosen to speak in Mandarin, the concern I have for the problems in Singapore is certainly not confined to the Chinese community alone. Although I am a Member of an Opposition party, I am also part of Singapore. My criticism on the policy of the Government as laid down in the President's Address cannot be viewed as a sign of disloyalty to Singapore. I would like to bring the voice of our people to Parliament, and without fear or favour to ensure that the Government considers the interest of the ordinary people when it passes any resolution.

    In the President's Address, the Government finally admits that for its policies to succeed it needs to have the universal support of the various communities, including those who do not converse in English and who are less vocal with their views. The Ministry of Community Development also admits, in its Addendum to the President's Address, that more care and concern must be given to the lower-income group.

    In his speech, Dr John Chen mentioned that some views presented by the formerWorkers Party's Non-Constituency MP, Dr Lee Siew-Choh, had also been accepted. Just now, Mr Chin Harn Tong mentioned that this policy speech is one which is full of compassion.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I feel that this is the will of the people. This is also the result brought about by the fact that our people had been sensible in voting in four members of the Opposition at the last General Election. However, I regret to say

Column: 147

that the President's Address has neglected the problems in our Singapore society which need to be discussed and dealt with urgently.

    Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong had said, before he became Prime Minister, that his Government would be an open and consultative one. This was also one of the slogans he used in his election campaign, urging the people to give him their support. The message given to Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong is clear and definite. People have moved away from their traditional reliance on the PAP. With the spirit of reason, confidence, and dauntless courage, they returned four members of the Opposition. This clearly illustrates the fact that our people's political consciousness has improved. They care for their nation and actively participate in the affairs of the nation. This is indeed heartening!

    Mr Speaker, Sir, if we look at the situation of the world today, we will see that in many countries, people paid dearly for their struggle and fight for democracy. Yet, the people of Singapore are able to progress in its development of democracy in a rational and peaceful manner. Is this not a matter for rejoicing? Yet, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said in the post-election press conference that he was going to review his open and consultative style. This is something which makes me very worried.

    In the President's Address and also in The Next Lap, there is no mention at all of the direction of our political development. Are we going back to the old ways of autocracy and closed-door policy, or do we go along with the global trend of moving towards greater democracy? We should allow everyone in our society to express their views legally and freely, through the various legitimate organisations in our society, so that everyone could be expounded with the realization of what is the truth, and what is national interest! Or through the restriction of open discussion and through the mass media, to inculcate our people with some kind of specific thought.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, many countries in the world today practise closed-door and

Column: 148

single-party domination policy. With the high efficiency of a centrally controlled system, they had enjoyed some moments of glory. However, not long later, their politics became degenerated, and the people were made to live in an abyss of misery. Eventually, the government collapsed and had to face disastrous consequences. These are lessons which we should draw from other people's mistakes.

    Our greatest challenge ahead is how to bring about a gracious society which is more just, equal and democratic, through the practice of open politics. At the same time, cultivate our people to better identify themselves with our country.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, education is a very important factor. In a country, the quality of its people, the performance of its economy, the development of its social works and the general mood of the society, are closely linked to the success or failure of its education system. Furthermore, as we all know, the only resource in Singapore is our human resource. The Government's subsidy on education is an investment on the future of our people and our nation. It must not be viewed as a form of consumptive subsidy. Education must not be regarded as a form of service.

    The former Workers Party's MP for Anson proposed in Parliament, in 1985, that we should provide educational subsidy and assist those in our society who were in financial difficulty, so that their children would have the best opportunity to be educated. Mr Speaker, Sir, many families are able to improve their standard of living because of the academic achievement of their children. Therefore, when the Government makes use of the reserve to subsidise on education, it should be done in a fair manner so as to benefit all the students. It should not make use of our limited resources to favour those who are gifted and whose results are better. It is said that education can also sharpen our competitive edge. Then, would it not be better to make the majority of our people more competitive, than just to improve the competitiveness of a handful of elites

Column: 149

who are talented and who have performed better in their studies?

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Preparatory Year for primary schools is enthusiastically welcomed by many parents. In fact, many parents were disappointed when their children could not find a place in the preparatory class. It is the wish of most parents in Singapore that the number of preparatory classes be increased so that every child in Singapore will have a chance to get in. However, I am surprised that the Government has, on its own accord, decided to discontinue with these classes in the schools. All along, our education system has been one which emphasizes on practical application. Applied sciences, no doubt, are good for our economic development. However, in order to transform Singapore into a gracious society, equal importance must be attached to the humanities.
